title: Kaiser Chiefs
text:
{{Short description|English indie rock band}}{{About|the band|the South African football club|Kaizer Chiefs F.C.}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2022}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Kaiser Chiefs | image = Jaguar XE - Arrival in London (14999312137).jpg | caption = Kaiser Chiefs at the launch of the [[Jaguar XE]] in 2014 {{break}}From left: [[Andrew White (musician)|Andrew White]], Simon Rix, [[Ricky Wilson (singer)|Ricky Wilson]], Nick Baines, Vijay Mistry | landscape = Yes | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Leeds]], England | years_active = 2000–present | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[Britpop]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/features/landfill-indie-snobbery-2741199|title=The term 'landfill indie' is nothing but musical snobbery|date=1 September 2020}} [[power pop]] | label = [[Universal Music Group|MCA Music, Inc.]], [[B-Unique Records|B-Unique]], [[Fiction Records|Fiction]], [[Polydor Records|Polydor]], [[Drowned in Sound]], [[Liberation Music|Liberator]], [[Caroline International]], [[ATO Records|ATO]] | website = {{URL|www.kaiserchiefs.com}} | current_members = [[Ricky Wilson (singer)|Ricky Wilson]]
[[Andrew White (musician)|Andrew White]]
Simon Rix
Nick Baines
Vijay Mistry | past_members = [[Nick Hodgson]] }} '''Kaiser Chiefs''' are an English [[indie rock]]{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/kaiser-chiefs-mn0000932328/biography|title=Kaiser Chiefs|work=Allmusic|access-date=30 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/sevenages/programmes/what-the-world-is-waiting-for|title= BBC – Seven Ages of Rock "What the World Is Waiting For"|year=2007|work=[[Seven Ages of Rock]]|access-date=2 March 2011}} band from [[Leeds]] who formed in 2000 as '''Parva''', releasing one studio album, ''22'', in 2003, before renaming and establishing themselves in their current name that same year. Since their formation the band has consisted of lead vocalist [[Ricky Wilson (singer)|Charles Richard Wilson]], [[guitarist]] [[Andrew White (musician)|Andrew "Whitey" White]], bassist [[Simon Rix]], keyboardist Nick "Peanut" Baines and since 2013 drummer Vijay Mistry, who replaced founding drummer [[Nick Hodgson]] following his departure from the band in late 2012.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/dec/05/kaiser-chiefs-songwriter-leaves-band |title=Kaiser Chiefs songwriter leaves band |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |last=Michaels |first=Sean |date=5 December 2012 |access-date=5 December 2012}} Primarily inspired by [[New wave music|new wave]] and [[punk rock]] music of the late 1970s and 1980s, the band have released seven original studio albums: ''[[Employment (album)|Employment]]'' (2005), ''[[Yours Truly, Angry Mob]]'' (2007), ''[[Off with Their Heads (album)|Off with Their Heads]]'' (2008), ''[[The Future Is Medieval]]'' (2011), ''[[Education, Education, Education & War]]'' (2014), [[Stay Together (album)|''Stay Together'']] (2016), and ''[[Duck (album)|Duck]]'' (2019), one EP: ''[[Lap of Honour]]'' (2005), one compilation album: ''[[Souvenir: The Singles 2004–2012]]'' (2012) and numerous singles, including the number one hit song "[[Ruby (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Ruby]]". Their album ''Employment'' enjoyed critical and commercial success with over three million copies sold.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kaiserchiefs.com/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911220758/http://www.kaiserchiefs.co.uk/index.php?s=bio|url-status=dead|title=KAISER CHIEFS | DUCK|archive-date=11 September 2007|website=Kaiser Chiefs}} It has won the band three [[Brit Awards]], including the award for Best British Group,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4600150.stm|title=Brit Awards 2006: The winners|date=15 February 2006|publisher=News.bbc.co.uk|access-date=27 September 2014}} a NME award for Best Album,{{cite web|title=ShockWave NME Awards : Full List of Winner 2006 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/nme-awards/22318 |website=Nme.com |access-date=15 June 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112160423/http://www.nme.com/news/nme-awards/22318 |archive-date=12 January 2012 }} and was shortlisted for the [[Mercury Prize]].Heather Phares. [{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r730702|pure_url=yes}} "Employment > Review"]. [[Allmusic]]. Retrieved 14 September 2007.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4217140.stm|title=Antony and Johnsons win Mercury|website=News.bbc.co.uk|date=7 September 2005|access-date=27 September 2014}} Their UK hit singles include 2004 and 2005 number 9 hit "[[I Predict a Riot]]", 2007 UK number 1 hit "[[Ruby (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Ruby]]", which has sold over 461,000 copies,{{cite web|last=Official|title=Official charts|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/reading-and-leeds-2012-official-top-40-biggest-selling-singles-revealed-1544/|access-date=23 August 2014}} from their platinum album ''[[Yours Truly, Angry Mob]]'' plus a further two Top 20 singles in 2007 with "[[The Angry Mob]]" and "[[Everything Is Average Nowadays]]". Their singles "[[Ruby (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Ruby]]", "[[I Predict a Riot]]", "[[Everyday I Love You Less and Less]]", "[[Never Miss a Beat]]" and "[[Oh My God (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Oh My God]]" had sold a combined total of 1.1 million up to August 2012. ==History== ===Parva and ''22'' (2000–2003)=== When they were around eleven years old, Nick Hodgson, Nick Baines and Simon Rix met in the same class at [[St. Mary's Catholic High School, Menston]], West Yorkshire.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/leeds/content/image_galleries/music_musical_map_of_leeds_gallery.shtml?10-|title=BBC Leeds – Musical Map of Leeds|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|access-date=27 September 2014}} After leaving school, Rix and Baines left for university in 1996 whereas Hodgson remained in the Leeds area, meeting both Andrew White and Ricky Wilson. Hodgson, White and Wilson formed the band Runston Parva, its name a deliberate misspelling of a small [[East Riding of Yorkshire|East Yorkshire]] hamlet called [[Ruston Parva]]. After Runston Parva failed to secure a record deal, the group re-formed as Parva upon the return of Rix and Baines from university. Parva's career went beyond the boundaries of Leeds, and the band was able to obtain both a record and publishing deal. However, after [[Beggars Banquet Records|Beggars Banquet]] closed the [[Mantra Recordings|Mantra]] label, Parva were dropped and left desolate and without any direction after the release of an album (''22'') and three singles ("Heavy", "Good Bad Right Wrong" and "Hessles"). According to manager James Sandom in an interview with [[HitQuarters]], as a dropped band they had become damaged goods, "No one would touch them because they had a history. A lot of people used their history against them."{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_James_Sandom_Interview.html |title=Interview with James Sandom |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=28 May 2007 |access-date=17 November 2010}} The band decided that they would aim for a longer term record deal and started afresh with new songs and a new name: Kaiser Chiefs. The new name was taken from South African football club [[Kaizer Chiefs F.C.|Kaizer Chiefs]], the first club of ex-[[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] captain [[Lucas Radebe]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/southyorkshire/content/articles/2005/04/14/kaiser_chiefs_interview.shtml|title=BBC - South Yorkshire - Entertainment - Kaiser Chiefs interview|website=Bbc.co.uk}} Manager James Sandom was tipped off about the band by [[Drowned in Sound]] founder Sean Adams, who persuaded him to go and see them live. Sandom said: "I went to see a couple of shows and you were just bombarded by a series of potential hit singles." Soon after Sandom became their manager, Kaiser Chiefs signed to [[B-Unique Records]]. [[Atlantic Records]] had also made an offer for the band. ===''Employment'' (2004–2005)=== [[File:Ricky wilson lollapalooza.jpg|thumb|upright|Performing at [[Lollapalooza]] in 2005]] In July 2004, while still relatively unknown inside the UK, Kaiser Chiefs performed their first festival outside the UK at a festival in [[Moscow]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/7580 |title=The Ordinary Boys/Kaiser Chiefs : Liquid Rooms, Edinburgh, Wed, Oct 6 |last1=Sterry |first1=Mike |date=6 December 2004 |publisher=[[NME]] |access-date=9 March 2013}} One of the major factors in the band's breakthrough in 2005 was their involvement in the NME Awards Tour at the beginning of the year.{{cite web|title=SHOCKWAVES NME AWARDS 2005|url=https://www.nme.com/news/nme-awards/19257|website=Nme.com|access-date=15 June 2011}} Like [[Coldplay]] and [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]] before them, their position as opening act proved an influential one, attracting a lot of positive media attention. The group's debut album ''[[Employment (album)|Employment]]'' was released in March 2005, being primarily inspired by [[New wave music|new wave]] and [[punk rock]] music of the late 1970s and 1980s. The album was well received by music critics, described as "thrilling from beginning to end" and "quintessentially British, without pretension and most importantly, a whole lot of fun".{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/kaiserchiefs/employment|title=Employment by Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Metacritic.com|access-date=27 September 2014}} It reached number two on the [[UK albums chart]],{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/album/13799|title=Employment Music Charts: Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Acharts.us|access-date=27 September 2014}} and was certified five times platinum.[http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=32536 British platinum certification for ''Employment'']. [[British Phonographic Industry]]. 17 February 2006. Retrieved 14 September 2007. In 2005, ''Employment'' was shortlisted for the [[Mercury Prize]], an annual music prize awarded for the best British or Irish album from the previous year. Bookmakers made it favourite to win the award, but they eventually lost out to [[Antony and the Johnsons]]. In 2006, ''[[Employment (album)|Employment]]'' won the Ivor Novello award for 'Best Album'{{cite web|title=Ivor Novello|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/23163|website=Nme.com|access-date=15 June 2011}} The first single released from the album was "[[Oh My God (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Oh My God]]" in 2004, which reached number six on the UK singles chart when it was reissued in February 2005. In 2007, the song was [[cover version|covered]] by [[Mark Ronson]] and [[Lily Allen]] for Ronson's album ''[[Version (album)|Version]]''. "[[I Predict a Riot]]" soon followed as the album's second release. In 2007, the song was ranked number thirty-six on the ''[[NME]]'' "Greatest Indie Anthems Ever" countdown.{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/28031 |title=The Greatest Indie Anthems Ever – countdown continues |website=Nme.com |access-date=27 September 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115192800/http://www.nme.com/news/28031 |archive-date=15 November 2014 }} The top twenty singles "[[Everyday I Love You Less and Less]]" and "[[Modern Way]]" followed in late 2005. The band opened and performed several of their singles at the [[Live 8 concert, Philadelphia|Philadelphia Live Eight]] concert in 2005. The song "Saturday Night" was featured in a pre-release video for the [[Xbox 360]] gaming console. It was posted on the official Xbox 360 page before its launch. In 2006, the band received NME awards for 'Best Album' for Employment and 'Best Dressed' for Ricky Wilson. ===''Yours Truly, Angry Mob'' (2006–2007)=== Kaiser Chiefs' second album ''[[Yours Truly, Angry Mob]]'' was released in February 2007. The group recorded the album throughout the September and October 2006 at [[Hookend Recording Studios]] in Oxfordshire, England. The group took inspiration from [[Led Zeppelin]] and American rock music, and recorded over twenty-two songs.{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/24815|title=The Kaiser Chiefs discuss new album|date=20 October 2006|website=Nme.com|access-date=27 September 2014}} ''Yours Truly, Angry Mob'' reached number one on the UK albums chart and number forty-five on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard 200|200 albums chart]].{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/album/14927|title=''Yours Truly, Angry Mob'' Music Charts: Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Acharts.us|access-date=27 September 2014}} The album went on to be the band's second Million Seller including the UK and European #1 Airplay Hit of 2007 "Ruby".{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/kaiserchiefs/yourstrulyangrymob?q=kaiser%20chiefs|title=Yours Truly, Angry Mob by Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Metacritic.com|access-date=27 September 2014}} "[[Ruby (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Ruby]]", the album's [[lead single]], became Kaiser Chiefs' first UK number one single{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/11990|title=Ruby Music Charts: Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Acharts.us|access-date=27 September 2014}} and received the 2007 'Q Award' for 'Best Video'.{{cite web|last=Q Magazine |title=Q Awards 2007 |url=http://www2.qawards.co.uk/2007/10/kaiser_chiefs_best_video.html |work=Kaiser Chiefs Best Video |publisher=IPC |access-date=15 June 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810045148/http://www2.qawards.co.uk/2007/10/kaiser_chiefs_best_video.html |archive-date=10 August 2011 }} "[[Everything Is Average Nowadays]]" was released as the album's second single, and reached No. 19 in the UK.{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/26066|title=Everything Is Average Nowadays Music Charts: Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Acharts.us|access-date=27 September 2014}} The album's third single "[[The Angry Mob]]" peaked at number twenty-two in the UK.{{cite web|url=http://kaiserchiefs.co.uk/index.php?s=press-view&press_id=95|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013143344/http://kaiserchiefs.co.uk/index.php?s=press-view&press_id=95|url-status=dead|archive-date=13 October 2007|title=Kaiser Chiefs - Press|date=13 October 2007|access-date=15 January 2019}}{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/27479|title=The Angry Mob Music Charts: Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Acharts.us|access-date=27 September 2014}} The fourth single, "[[Love's Not a Competition (But I'm Winning)]]", was released on 12 November as a collector's edition 7" only single via their website. In December 2007, Kaiser Chiefs played two sold-out shows at Earl's Court in London{{cite web|last=Click Music News|title=Kaiser Chiefs add second London date|url=http://www.clickmusic.com/news/article/Kaiser-Chiefs-Add-Second-London-Date|work=Click Music News- Kaiser Chiefs add second London date|access-date=15 June 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817120347/http://www.clickmusic.com/news/article/Kaiser-Chiefs-Add-Second-London-Date|archive-date=17 August 2011}} to a capacity crowd of 30,000.{{cite web|last=Earl's Court Public Event|title=ECO Public Event Space|url=http://www.eco.co.uk/p/public-event-space/157|access-date=15 June 2011}} ===''Off with Their Heads'' (2008–2009)=== [[File:KC stage Elland Rd 240508.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The stage at [[Elland Road|Elland Road stadium]] on 24 May 2008.]] On 4 August 2008, the band confirmed the name of their third album as ''[[Off with Their Heads (album)|Off with Their Heads]]''. It was released on 20 October 2008. The first single "[[Never Miss a Beat]]" was released on 6 October 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/a118969/kaisers-reveal-off-with-their-heads-lp.html |title=Kaisers reveal Off With Their Heads LP |access-date=4 August 2008 |date=4 August 2008 |work=Digital Spy}} The band also released a DVD of their live performance at Elland Road from 24 May where they played to a sold out capacity crowd of 40,000 people.{{cite web|last=Amazon|title=Live At Elland Road|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Kaiser-Chiefs-Live-Elland-Road/dp/B001IBCY36|work=Kaiser Chiefs Live At Elland Road|publisher=Amazon|access-date=15 June 2011}} The DVD contains the full set from the home of Leeds United as well as highlights from the Kaiser Chiefs performance for the 2007 BBC Electric Proms. Kaiser Chiefs set out on a UK tour in October 2008 with Castle Donington band [[Late of the Pier]] and [[The Hair]]. The tour started at [[Leeds Academy]], a new venue where they were the first headlining band to play. Other dates included Manchester Academy, Southampton Guildhall, Reading Rivermead, Glasgow Barrowlands, Leicester De Montfort Hall and London Forum.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} Kaiser Chiefs headed out on a UK Arena tour between February and March 2009, kicking off in Nottingham and ending in London. The tour visited Sheffield, Birmingham, Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool, Cardiff and Dublin. This was the new album tour to promote ''Off with Their Heads''. The band featured on several shows over Christmas 2008 including performing "Never Miss a Beat" with [[Girls Aloud]] on their TV Special and playing the same song on the Christmas Day edition of ''[[Top of the Pops]]''. On 16 July 2009, they played at Marés Vivas in Vila Nova de Gaia, Portugal as headliners on that day. They, along with [[Republic of Loose]], opened for [[U2]] in [[Croke Park]] in Dublin on 25 July 2009. They then opened for [[Green Day]] from 27 July to 7 August 2009, and the final shows before their 2-year hiatus were performed at [[Reading and Leeds Festival]] 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsfestival.com/ |title=Home – Leeds Festival 2011 |publisher=Leedsfestival.com |access-date=21 July 2011}} === ''The Future Is Medieval'' (2010–2011) === Following a hiatus, Kaiser Chiefs announced that they expected to release their fourth studio album in mid-2011. The album was recorded over a period of eighteen months at various locations including drummer Nick Hodgson's self-built east-London studio.{{cite news|last=Peter|first=Paphides|title=Kaiser Chiefs But Under Your Control|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/jun/03/kaiser-chiefs-the-future-is-medieval|work=Kaiser Chiefs The Future Is Medieval|publisher=The Guardian (www.theguardian.com)|access-date=15 June 2011|location=London|date=3 June 2011}} The album's producers included [[Tony Visconti]], [[Ethan Johns]] and [[Owen Morris]], in addition to Nick Hodgson himself.{{cite web|title=The Kaiser Chiefs Self-Release 'The Future Is Medieval'|url=http://www.sentimentalistmag.com/2011/06/04/the-kaiser-chiefs-self-release-the-future-is-medieval/|work=The Sentamentalist Magazine|publisher=The Sentamentalist Magazine|access-date=15 June 2011}} On 3 June 2011, Kaiser Chiefs launched their new album from their website. Using a create-your-own album technique, fans were able to choose 10 out of 20 songs to create "their album" for [[GBP|£]]7.50; the band provides streams of roughly one minute to preview each track before selection. Many celebrities including, Radio One DJ [[Chris Moyles]], [[The Guardian|The Guardian Newspaper]], and frontman Ricky Wilson, created their own version of the album, donating the £1 reimbursement for each copy sold to the [[Alzheimer's Society]].{{cite web|title=Kaiser Chiefs support Alzheimer's Society with the launch of their new album|url=http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=982|publisher=[[Alzheimer's Society]]|access-date=15 June 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919062548/http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=982|archive-date=19 September 2011}} On 27 June 2011, Kaiser Chiefs released an official track listing for the album, featuring 12 of the 20 available tracks and including a previously unheard track 'Kinda Girl You Are' which did not make the initial launch as it was not ready in time.{{cite web|title=Kaiser Chiefs New |url=http://www.kaiserchiefs.com/home/BandNews |work=Kaiser Chiefs Band News |publisher=Kaiser Chiefs.com |access-date=15 June 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606033359/http://www.kaiserchiefs.com/home/BandNews |archive-date=6 June 2011 }} They played two sell out comeback gigs at Falmouth Princess Pavilion. Then followed by appearances at Germany's Hurricane and Southside Festivals in June, Switzerland's [[Gurtenfestival|Gurten Festival]], [[Pinkpop]] in The Netherlands, Belgium's [[Rock Werchter]], Portuguese festival Optimus Alive! in July, [[V Festival]] in August, [[Hard Rock Calling]] in June, the [[Isle of Wight Festival 2011|Isle of Wight Festival]] in June and at Terres Rouges Festival in Luxembourg in September. They also played at [[Tennants Vital]] in Bangor, Northern Ireland and in September they played two sold-out home town shows at [[Kirkstall Abbey]] in Leeds. They also be played in October in Festa das Latas, Coimbra – Portugal. On 6 March 2012 the album was re-released under the title ''[[The Future Is Medieval|Start The Revolution Without Me]]'' for the US market. The track list differs significantly from the initial release, including the track "On The Run", which is exclusive to the US album and served as its lead single in early 2012. ===''Souvenir'', Hodgson's departure (2012–2013)=== [[File:KaiserChiefs-Greenville-Festival-2013-9.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ricky Wilson (British musician)|Ricky Wilson]] in concert in Germany in 2013.]] In early 2012, Kaiser Chiefs played a 20 date tour of the United Kingdom, followed by a tour of North America.{{cite web|title=Kaiser Chiefs Announce US Album/Tour|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/61479 |website=Nme.com|access-date=23 January 2012}}{{cite web|title=Kaiser Chiefs Announce UK Tour|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/58726 |website=Nme.com|access-date=23 January 2012}} Kaiser Chiefs released their first compilation album, ''[[Souvenir: The Singles 2004–2012]]'', in the UK on 4 June 2012. The album features all of the singles released by the band from 2004 to 2012, as well as a new track titled "Listen to Your Head". Drummer Nick Hodgson revealed via his Twitter account on 4 December 2012 that he had left the band to concentrate on other projects.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisfakediy.co.uk/articles/news/drummer-nick-hodgson-leaves-kaiser-chiefs/ |title=Drummer Nick Hodgson Leaves Kaiser Chiefs|publisher=Thisisfakediy.co.uk |access-date=13 December 2012}} The band later issued a statement on their website confirming this.{{cite web|url=http://www.kaiserchiefs.com/news/band-statement-on-nicks-departure |title=Band statement on Nick's departure | News |publisher=Kaiser Chiefs |access-date=13 December 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121207034940/http://www.kaiserchiefs.com/news/band-statement-on-nicks-departure |archive-date=7 December 2012 }} On 7 February 2013 it was announced that Vijay Mistry from the band [[Club Smith]] would be joining the Kaiser Chiefs as their new drummer. The band were one of two support bands for [[Green Day]]'s one-off concert at the Emirates Stadium in London on 1 June 2013 along with [[All Time Low]]. The band's UK tour included 13 shows, beginning at Carlisle Sands Centre on 11 February and ending at London's O2 Academy Brixton on 1 March. The run of shows also includes gigs in Glasgow, Dunfermline, Manchester, Bridlington, Newcastle, Preston, Cheltenham, Wolverhampton, Southampton, Margate and Cambridge. They then went on to headline one of the Eden Sessions at the [[Eden Project]], Cornwall. They played a hometown concert at the [[First Direct Arena]] in September 2013, being one of the first artists to perform at the new venue.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/calendar/2012-11-27/leeds-kaiser-chiefs-return-home-to-play-leeds-arena/ |title=Leeds Kaiser Chiefs return home to play Leeds arena | Calendar - ITV News |publisher=Itv.com |date=27 November 2012 |access-date=13 December 2012}} ===''Education, Education, Education & War'' (2014–2015)=== The band's fifth studio album, titled ''[[Education, Education, Education & War]]'' was released on 31 March 2014.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/education-education-education/id780584347 |title=Education, Education, Education & War by Kaiser Chiefs |date=January 2014 |publisher=[[iTunes]] |access-date=6 January 2014}} ''Education, Education, Education & War'' is the first album featuring the new Kaiser Chiefs drummer, Vijay Mistry, after [[Nick Hodgson]] left the group in December 2012. The album was produced by Ben H. Allen III (who has previously worked with [[Gnarls Barkley]], [[Animal Collective]], and [[Deerhunter]]), and recorded at The Maze Studio in [[Atlanta]]. Three songs were co-written with [[Fraser T Smith]] ([[CeeLo Green]], [[Adele]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/74190 |title=Kaiser Chiefs announce new album – watch |work=[[NME]] |date=3 December 2013 |access-date=3 January 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/12/kaiser-chiefs-education-war-album-trailer-track-list/ |title=Kaiser Chiefs Preview Fifth Album 'Education, Education, Education & War' |work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |first=Chris |last=Martins |date=3 December 2013 |access-date=3 January 2014}} It was mixed by [[Michael Brauer]] ([[My Morning Jacket]], [[Coldplay]]) at [[Electric Lady Studios]] in [[New York City]] in November 2013.{{cite web|url=http://atorecords.com/featured/kaiser-chiefs-announce-new-album-out-april-1st/ |title=KAISER CHIEFS Announce New Album Out April 1st. Pre-Order Now |publisher=[[ATO Records]] |date=3 December 2013 |access-date=6 January 2014}} On 5 December 2013, Kaiser Chiefs released a song titled "Misery Company" onto their [[SoundCloud]] account. The song had previously been performed live during the band's 2013 summer tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a537116/kaiser-chiefs-debut-new-song-misery-company-listen.html |title=Kaiser Chiefs debut new song 'Misery Company' - listen |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |first=Lewis |last=Corner |date=10 December 2013 |access-date=6 January 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/74333 |title=Kaiser Chiefs unveil new track 'Misery Company' – listen |work=[[NME]] |date=10 December 2013 |access-date=6 January 2013}} On 3 January 2014, "Bows & Arrows" premiered on ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine's website. ''Education, Education, Education & War'' was toured across Europe and the Americas throughout 2014 and 2015. In 2015, they supported the ''[[Foo Fighters]]'' during the South Africa, South America and Ireland legs of their ''[[Sonic Highways World Tour]]''. They also released stand alone single 'Falling Awake' on 27 January 2015 via their YouTube channel. === ''Stay Together'' (2016–2017) === ''[[Stay Together (album)|Stay Together]]'', the band's sixth studio album, was released on 7 October 2016. It was co-written and produced by [[Brian Higgins(producer)|Brian Higgins]], whose production company [[Xenomania]] has worked with the likes of [[Girls Aloud]] and [[Pet Shop Boys]]. The album's name is a reference to the song "We Stay Together".{{Cite web|url=http://www.radiox.co.uk/artists/kaiser-chiefs/music/listen-kaiser-chiefs-unveil-parachute-single/#hOwt3Dfjk7RI9FQ3.97|title=LISTEN: KAISER CHIEFS UNVEIL PARACHUTE SINGLE {{!}} Radiox.co.uk/|last=Radiox.co.uk|website=Radiox.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=13 June 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/kaiser-chiefs/91644|title=Kaiser Chiefs working on new album of love songs |website=Nme.com|language=en-GB|access-date=7 May 2016}} The first single from the album, "[[Parachute (Kaiser Chiefs song)|Parachute]]", was released on 14 June 2016. The second single, "Hole In My Soul" was released 18 August 2016 and the third and final single, "We Stay Together" was released on 9 December 2016. This welcome return to the limelight saw ‘Stay Together’ push new boundaries to "take this nondescript sound and stuff it impressively full of sing-a-long hooks, covering topics including monogamy (We Stay Together) and shagging (Good Clean Fun)" as it marked an entirely new direction for the band, who went for a more dance-oriented sound.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/oct/06/kaiser-chiefs-stay-together-review-caroline|title=Kaiser Chiefs: Stay Together review – nondescript but still full of hooks|website=The Guardian|date=6 October 2016|access-date=17 May 2017|last1=Aroesti|first1=Rachel}} While ''[[Education, Education, Education and War]]'' was more focused on politics and the perils of war, the Kaiser Chiefs made the album with a focus on love and relationships. Wilson elaborated further on the stark contrast between this last album and 'Stay Together': "The thing about writing a protest album is it's straightforward. Only an idiot would disagree with you. You're just saying war is bad. But when you start talking about relationships like on this record it's harder because there’s a lot more blurred line. There's no right or wrong."{{cite web|last1=Trefor|first1=Cai|title=Kaiser Chiefs' Ricky Wilson Opens Up About New Album Stay Together|url=http://www.gigwise.com/blogs/108272/kaiser-chiefs-stay-together-new-album-parachute-hole-in-my-soul|website=Gigwise|access-date=13 October 2016|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014061046/http://www.gigwise.com/blogs/108272/kaiser-chiefs-stay-together-new-album-parachute-hole-in-my-soul|archive-date=14 October 2016}} The band performed a string of best of forest shows in the summer of 2016 as part the ''[[Forestry Commission]]'''s ''Forest Live'' series. Stay Together was toured across Europe in early 2017. ===''Duck'' (2018–present)=== The band signed with their original label [[Polydor Records]] for their seventh studio album, ''[[Duck (album)|Duck]]'', which released on 26 July 2019. For the album the band reunited with [[Ben H. Allen]], the producer who worked on the band's 2014 album ''[[Education, Education, Education & War]]''. The album was preceded by a UK tour in January and February, including concerts at London's [[O2 Academy Brixton]] and [[O2 Academy Birmingham]], where several new songs from the album were premiered. The band also played a homecoming show at Elland Road in Leeds on 8 June 2019. Duck was later toured around arenas in the UK and Europe in early 2020. The first single from the album, "Record Collection", was released on 23 May 2019, with "People Know How To Love One Another" released as a second single on 6 June 2019. "Golden Oldies" was released as the third single in October 2019. The name sparked interest with fans which was the opposite of what the band wanted. According to Wilson, they had always had trouble naming records so went with a random title suggested by White. Although the album entered at number three in the UK charts, it rapidly fell out of the list after only two weeks.{{cite web |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/15414/kaiser-chiefs/ |title=Kaiser Chiefs |website=Official Charts|access-date=28 March 2020}} In October 2022, the band announced the single "How 2 Dance", which will be released on November 4th. {{cite web |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Cj47VQgKWLx/ |title=Kaiser Chiefs |website=Instagram|access-date=19 October 2022}} ==Other appearances== In July 2005 they were chosen to open Bob Geldof's [[Live 8]] festival in [[Philadelphia]]; their performance was broadcast by satellite to every Live 8 venue around the world, giving the band massive worldwide exposure. In August 2006, the band released a book entitled ''A Record of Employment'', which along with photos by Peter Hill, documented the band's rise from being unsigned to their triumph at the Brit Awards that year, where the band won awards for 'Best British Band','Best Rock Act' and 'Best New Artist'. Later a DVD entitled ''Enjoyment'', which documented concerts from the first album era was released, this showed members of the band hypothetically interviewed when 'jaded rock stars'. In October 2008, they also appeared on MTV Day, in Greece, along with bands like the (Greek) C-Real, REM and the singer [[Gabriella Cilmi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtvgreece.gr/article.php?id=2399&category_id=28 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20110721083554/http://www.mtvgreece.gr/article.php?id=2399&category_id=28 |url-status=dead |archive-date=21 July 2011 |title=R.E.M, Kaiser Chiefs, C:Real & Gabriella Cilmi |publisher=MTVGreece.gr |access-date=21 July 2011 }} During an appearance on the Late Show with David Letterman, David Letterman spoke to Nick Hodgson about buying the Kaiser Chiefs drum set after a brief discussion between the pair an undisclosed price was agreed. At the end of the Kaiser Chiefs show at Chicago's House of Blues (19 April 2012) Nick Hodgson announced this was the final show for his drum kit, which was to be sent to David Letterman. On 12 August 2012, the band was featured in the [[2012 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] of the [[London 2012 Olympics]], playing "[[Pinball Wizard]]" by [[The Who]]. In October 2014, Kaiser Chiefs played at [[The New Adelphi Club]] in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]], [[East Riding of Yorkshire|East Yorkshire]] as headline act for the venue's 30th anniversary celebration.{{cite news |title=Hull's a poppin' |url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/arts-and-culture/hulls-poppin-1833896 |access-date=10 January 2021 |work=Yorkshire Post |date=28 September 2014}} A film capturing Kaiser Chiefs performance was made, which was shown at the Adelphi in January 2015 as part of Independent Music Venue Week. In October 2015, the film was screened at the 2015 [[Tucson Film & Music Festival]] in [[Tucson, Arizona|Arizona]], United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.codhead.co.uk/kaiser-chiefs-live-at-the-hull-adelphi.html |title=Kaiser Chiefs Live At The Hull Adelphi |website=Codhead.co.uk |access-date=16 February 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307112715/http://www.codhead.co.uk/kaiser-chiefs-live-at-the-hull-adelphi.html |archive-date=7 March 2016}} The band were the closing act for F1 Live (an event showcasing [[Formula 1]] ahead of the 2017 British Grand Prix) held in Trafalgar Square, London on 12 July 2017, which was also broadcast live on Sky Sports. In September 2022 Kaiser Chiefs headlined Pub in The Park in St Albans to huge acclaim. ==Awards and nominations== '''Antville Music Video Awards''' {{award table}} |- | 2007 | "[[The Angry Mob]]" |
